title: TESOL Curriculum & Methodology
requirements: For students in MA Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
description: This course covers the fundamental concepts related to (I) the TESOL curriculum and (II) English language teaching methodology. Part I aims to provide general coverage of important theories and issues concerning the curriculum with an emphasis on curricular design, implementation, and evaluation. Part II comprises an overview of various major language teaching methods as well as those specific to listening, reading, speaking, and writing. Students are expected to participate actively in teaching demonstrations in order to better grasp and reflect on the different approaches introduced.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: - gain a good understanding of the relevant theories and issues related to the TESOL curriculum- design, implement, and evaluate a curriculum making reference to relevant frameworks - demonstrate a good grasp of various major language teaching methods - describe, demonstrate, and evaluate specific teaching methods related to listening, reading, speaking, and writing (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
syllabus: Part I 1. Defining ‘curriculum’ and related concepts such as syllabi2. Major theories, frameworks, and issues related to the English language curriculum including its recent and current development 3. Design, implementation, and evaluation of the English language curriculum Part II4. Major language teaching methods (e.g. Communicative Language Teaching (CLT), Task-Based Language Teaching (TBLT)) and their history 5. Teaching methods specific to listening, reading, speaking, and writing6. Demonstrating and evaluating the teaching methods introduced (For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

title: Second Language Acquisition
requirements: For students in MA Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
description: This course focuses on a number of contemporary theories and issues in second language acquisition (SLA) with the aim of preparing students for applications both in research and teaching. Topics will include, but are not limited to, internal factors, external factors, sociocultural aspects, cognition, metacognition, and learning strategies related to SLA. Recent research developments in the field in SLA will also be introduced for students to better understand practical applications of SLA theories. Students will be expected to read research articles in order to develop a solid foundation in SLA theories and their applications.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to:•    Gain a good understanding of contemporary SLA theories;•    Critique a range of issues related to SLA with reference to teaching and learning; •    Show a good understanding of applications of SLA theories to research and teaching; •    Demonstrate the ability to conceptualize empirical research guided by SLA theories. (Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
syllabus: 1.    Learner errors and analysis2.    Individual learner differences3.    Interlanguage4.    The zone of proximal development (ZPD)5.    Input and interaction  6.    Cognitive aspects of learning7.    Metacognitive aspects of learning8.    Language learning strategies (Please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

title: Second Language Assessment
requirements: For students in MA Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
description: This course introduces students to theoretical foundations and key concepts of second language assessment, such as reliability, validity, authenticity and washback. It examines basic principles of test design and evaluation and equips students with skills to construct, critique, adapt and score language tests, to conduct test item analysis, and to report and interpret test results. The course also discusses language assessment in relation to summative and formative assessment, assessment of, for and as learning, and alternative assessment, with specific reference to how assessment can be used to support classroom instruction. Students will be provided with opportunities for hands-on practice and to reflect critically on conventional assessment approaches in the light of best practices in language assessment.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: demonstrate a solid understanding of key theoretical concepts of second language assessment; construct, critique, adapt and score language tests; conduct test item analysis; and report and interpret test results; develop a strong grasp of summative and formative assessment, assessment of, for and as learning, and alternative assessment, with specific reference to how assessment can be used to support classroom instruction; and reflect critically on conventional assessment approaches in the light of best practices in language assessment.(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
syllabus: Key concepts in language assessment Constructing language tests Item analysis in language testing Scoring techniques (e.g. different kinds of scoring schemes; developing scoring rubrics) Reporting and interpreting test results Summative and formative assessment Assessment of, for and as learning Alternative assessment Evaluation and critique of language tests(Please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

title: Research Methods in TESOL
requirements: For students in MA Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
description: This course introduces research methods in TESOL with the goal of equipping students with the knowledge and skills to evaluate research in terms of appropriate research design, data collection instruments, and analytical procedures. The first part of the course discusses the major research traditions in TESOL, with a particular focus on classroom-based, practitioner research. The second part of the course examines a range of data collection techniques in relation to concepts such as internal/external reliability and validity. Authentic data will also be provided to students so that they can gain practical skills in qualitative and quantitative data analysis. Throughout the course, students will be expected to regularly read articles in academic journals with the aim of building an awareness of current research issues and developing their own research interests.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: Discuss and evaluate different research methods in TESOL; Formulate research questions relating to issues in TESOL and suggest appropriate research designs to investigate these issues; Define, exemplify and discuss key concepts and terms including external/internal reliability and validity, construct operationalization, and variables; Critique a range of data collection procedures and methods, including introspection, diary studies, questionnaires, interviews, and discoursal analysis; and Demonstrate the ability to analyze sample qualitative and quantitative data.(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
syllabus: Types of data, variables, and constructs Experimental and non-experimental designs Action research and exploratory practice Surveys and introspective data collection  Observing and analyzing classroom interaction Qualitative and quantitative data analysis Research ethics(For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)

title: Independent Research Project
requirements: For students in MA Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
description: This course provides an opportunity for students to explore a significant issue in TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages) through undertaking an independent research project. Under the guidance of a supervisor, students will conceive, design and carry to completion the research study on an individual basis. They will survey relevant literature, formulate research questions, work out an appropriate methodological design, gather data, engage in critical data analysis, and report on the study in a dissertation of 8,000 to 10,000 words. Before embarking on the study, students will submit a research proposal that includes a literature review, research questions, methodology, and an implementation plan.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: conceive, design and carry to completion an independent research study that explores a significant issue in TESOL;  conduct a thorough review of literature pertinent to the research study; demonstrate skills in the collection and critical analysis of data; write up the research study into a dissertation of 8,000 to 10,000 words; and make an original contribution to the field of study through the independent research study.(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary.)
syllabus: Theoretical and practical rationale of research Review of literature Research design Data collection and analysis Reporting of findings Implications, limitations and future research(For reference only, please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details.)
